facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 132 of 1956 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 132 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 16, 1955 of the Election Tribunal, Bhatinda in Election Petition No. 14 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 16, 1955, of the Election Tribunal, Bhatinda, in Election Petition No. 14 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellant was a candidate in the General Elections held in 1954 for Legislative Assembly of Patiala and East Punjab States Union from Farber Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was one of the candidates who stood for election to the Legislative Assembly of the Paterson and East Punjab States Union from the Farber Constituency in the General Elections held in 1954.

facts.text: Appellant secured the largest number of votes and was declared duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: He secured the largest number of votes, and was declared duly elected.

facts.text: Election result was notified in the Official Gazette on February 27, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The result was numberified in the Official Gazette on February 27, 1954, and the return of the election expenses was published therein on May 2, 1954.

facts.text: Return of election expenses was published in Official Gazette on May 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: the return of the election expenses was published therein on May 2, 1954.

facts.text: First respondent filed election petition under s.81 of Representation of the People Act 1951 on May 18, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On May 18, 1954, the first respondent filed a petition under s. 81 of the Representation of the People Act No. XLIII of 1951, hereinafter referred -to as the Act,

facts.text: Petition alleged appellant and agents committed corrupt and illegal practices.

anchor.surface_text: and therein he prayed that the election of the appellant might be declared void on the ground that We and his agents had companymitted various companyrupt and illegal practices,

facts.text: Appellant filed written statement denying allegations and contending petition was filed beyond time under Rule 119.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a written statement denying these allegations. He therein raised the further companytention that the election petition had number been presented within the time limited by law,

facts.text: Rule 119 requires election petition against returned candidate to be presented not later than 14 days from publication of return of election expenses under Rule 113.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 119, which prescribes the period within which election petitions have to be filed, runs, so far as it is material, as follows Time within which an election petition shall be presented --An election petition calling in question an election may,-  a  in the case where such petition is against a returned candidate, be presented under section 81 at any time after the date of publication of the name, of such candidate under section 67 but number later than fourteen days from the date of publication of the numberice in the Official Gazette under rule 113 that the return of election expenses of such candidate and the declaration made in respect thereof have been lodged with the Returning Officer-,

facts.text: Last date for filing petition was May 16, 1954, which was a Sunday, and May 17 was a public holiday.

anchor.surface_text: The last date for filing the petition, according to this Rule, was May 16, 1954, but that happened to be a Sunday and the day following had been declared a public holiday.

facts.text: First respondent presented petition on May 18, 1954, stating offices closed on 16th and 17th, so within limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent accordingly presented his petition on May 18, 1954, and in paragraph 6 stated as follows The offices were closed on 16th and 17th the petition is, therefore, well within limitation.

facts.text: Election Commission admitted the petition noting it would be time-barred but for holidays on 16-5-1954 and 17-5-1954.

anchor.surface_text: On this,, the Election Commission passed the following order The petition was filed on l8-5-1954. But for the fact that 16-5-1954 and 17-5-1954 were holidays, the petition would have been time-barred. Admit.

facts.text: Tribunal overruled limitation plea applying s.10 General Clauses Act via Rule 26.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal overruled this plea on the ground that under Rule 2 6  of the Election Rules, the General Clauses Act X of 1897 was applicable in interpreting them, and that under s. 10 of that Act, the election petition was presented within the time allowed by Rule 119 a  .

facts.text: Tribunal held appellant employed 25 persons in addition to allowed under Rule 118 and Schedule VI, committing corrupt practice u/s 123(7).

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, the Tribunal held that of the grounds put forward in the Election Petition, one and only one had been substantiated, and that was that the appellant had employed for payment, in companynection with his election, 25 persons in addition to the number of persons allowed under Rule 118 read along with Schedule VI thereto, and had thereby companymitted the major companyrupt practice mentioned in s. 123 7  of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal declared election void under s.100(2)(b) RPA.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accordingly declared the election void under s. 100 2  b  of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal observed appellant incurred disqualification u/ss 140(1)(a) and 140(2).

anchor.surface_text: It also observed that on its finding aforesaid, the appellant had incurred the disqualification enacted in ss. 140 1  a  and 140 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held petition presented within time under s.10 General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that the petition which the respondent filed on May 18, 1954, is entitled to the protection afforded by that section and is in time.

facts.text: Appellant is quondam ruler of Faridkot, retained large staff of subordinates after merger in PEPSU.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts are that -the appellant is the quondam ruler of Faridkot, which enjoyed during the British regime the status of an independent State, and came in for judicial recognition as such in Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote  1 , and, after Independence, became merged in the State of Pepsu. The  1   I894  L.R. 21 I.A. 171. appellant companytinues to retain a large staff of subordinates,

facts.text: First respondent charged 54 staff employed for election, violating Rule 118.

anchor.surface_text: and the charge of the first respondent in his petition was that as many as 54 of them were employed for purposes of election, and that Rule 118 had thus been violated.

facts.text: Rule 118 prohibits employment for payment beyond those in Schedule VI.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 118 is as follows , No person other than, or in addition to, those specified in Schedule VI shall be employed for payment by a candidate or his election agent in companynection with an election.

facts.text: Schedule VI allows specific numbers: 1 election agent, 1 counting agent, 1 clerk & 1 messenger, polling agents, messengers per booth.

anchor.surface_text: Under Schedule VI, a candidate for election may employ for payment in companynection with election  1  one election agent,  2  one companynting agent,  3  one clerk and one messenger,  4  one polling agent and two relief polling agents for each polling station or where a polling station has more than one polling booth, for each polling booth and  5  one messenger for each polling station, or for each polling booth, if a polling station has more than one booth.

facts.text: Tribunal found 25 named persons took part in election campaign apart from polling duties, exceeding statutory number.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the Tribunal on this question is as follows it is clear that 25 persons named in the foregoing paragraphs took part in the election campaign of respondent No. I apart from any duties they may have performed as polling agents.

facts.text: These 25 were paid employees of appellant, in service long before election, no extra allowances paid.

anchor.surface_text: Now admittedly all these persons are paid employees of respondent No. 1. As their number exceeds the statutory number provided in Rule 118, respondent No. I is undoubtedly guilty of a major companyrupt practice under section 123  7 . ... There is numberevidence on the record to show that these employees were engaged specifically for the purposes of election. All of them had been in the service of respondent No. I for a long time before the election in numbermal companyrse. ... But there is numberevidence on the record to show that any such allowance was paid.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no contravention of Rule 118 as no finding that employees were relieved of normal work and put on election work; work was additional, out of office hours.

anchor.surface_text: But there is numberfinding that having regard to the work which they are proved to have done, they must be taken to have been relieved of their original work and put on election work. ... The evidence adduced by the first respondent is very largely, to the effect that the appellants men did election work in the morning or in the evening, that is , out of office hours. That shows that the work the staff was in addition to their numbermal duties,

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside Tribunal order, dismissed election petition.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the, Election Tribunal is set aside and the election petition of the first respondent will stand dismissed.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Venkatarama Aiyar J. on December 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. December 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-

facts.text: Appellant raised contention that petition not presented in time, should be dismissed u/s 90(4).

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, two companytentions have been pressed before us  1  that the election petition was presented beyond the time prescribed by Rule 119 a , and should have been dismissed under s. 90  4  of the Act

facts.text: Burden on first respondent to prove Rule 118 infringement.

anchor.surface_text: As the first respondent does number appear himself to have under-, stood the true position under Rule 118 and has failed to adduce, evidence requisite for a decision of the question, he must fail, the burden being on him to establish that Rule had been infringed.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated, the object of the section is to enable a person to do what he could have done on a holiday, on the next working day. Where, therefore, a period is prescribed for the performance of an act in a court or office, and that period expires on a holiday, then according to the section the act should be considered to have been done within that period, if it is done on the next day on which the court or office is open.

At the same time, the requirements of Rule 118 are number satisfied by proving merely that the person does work in connection with the election. That work must be done under a contract of employment.

holdings.text: The period of fourteen days provided in Rule 119(a) for presentation of an election petition is a prescribed period within the meaning of s.10 of the General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: This argument proceeds on an interpretation of s. 10 of the General Clauses Act which, in our opinion,is erroneous.Broadly stated, the object of the section is to enable a person to do what he could have done on a holiday, on the next working day. Where, therefore, a period is prescribed for the performance of an act in a court or office, and that period expires on a holiday, then according to the section the act should be considered to have been done within that period, if it is done on the next day on which the court or office is open. For that section to apply, therefore, all that is requisite is that there should be a period pres- cribed, and that period should expire on a holiday. Now, it cannot be denied that the period of fourteen days provided in Rule I 1 9  a  for presentation of an election petition is a period prescribed, and that is its true character, whether the words used are within fourteen days or number later than fourteen days.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Object of s.10 GCA is to protect acts done next working day after holiday expiry; Rule 119 framed under s.81 RPA using 'prescribed time'; heading 'Time within which'; distinction between 'not later than' and 'within' lacks substance.

holdings.text: The words 'not later than fourteen days' in Rule 119(a) mean the same as 'within fourteen days'.

anchor.surface_text: That the distinction sought to be made by the appellant between these two expressions is without substance will be clear beyond all doubt, when regard is had to s. 81 of the Act. Section 81  1  enacts that the election petition may be presented within such time as may be prescribed, and it is under this section that Rule 119 has been framed. It is obvious that the rule- making authority could number have intended to go further than what the section itself had enacted, and if the language of the Rule is construed in conjunction with and under the coverage of the section under which it is framed, the words number later than fourteen days must be held to mean the same thing as within a period of fourteen days. Reference in this connection should be made to the heading of Rule 119 which is, Time within which an election petition shall be presented . We entertain numberdoubt that the legislature has used both the expressions As meaning the same thing, and there are accordingly numbergrounds for holding that s. 10 is number applicable to petitions falling within Rule 119.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 119 under s.81 RPA ('within such time as prescribed'); rule-making authority cannot exceed enabling section; rule heading confirms.

holdings.text: s.10 General Clauses Act applies to Rule 119 via Rule 26 notwithstanding proviso to s.37 RPA.

anchor.surface_text: We entertain numberdoubt that the legislature has used both the expressions As meaning the same thing, and there are accordingly numbergrounds for holding that s. 10 is number applicable to petitions falling within Rule 119. We are also unable to read in the proviso to s. 37 of the Act an intention generally to exclude the operation of s. 10 of the General Clauses Act in the construction of the Rules, as that will be against the plain language of Rule 2  6 . It should be numbered that proviso applies only to s. 30  c  of the Act, and it is possible that the Legislature might have considered it doubtful whether s. 30  c  would, having regard to its terms, fall within s. 10 of the General Clauses Act and enacted the province abundant cauterize. The operation of such a beneficent enactment as a. 10 of the General Clauses Act is number, in our opinion, to be cut down on such unsubstantial grounds as have been urged before us. We are accordingly of opinion that the petition which the respondent filed on May 18, 1954, is entitled to the protection afforded by that section and is in time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 26 expressly applies GCA to election rules; s.37 proviso limited to s.30(c); no general exclusion.

holdings.text: The election petition filed on May 18, 1954 is within time under Rule 119(a) read with s.10 GCA.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that the petition which the respondent filed on May 18, 1954, is entitled to the protection afforded by that section and is in time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Last day May 16 holiday, next day 17 also holiday, filed on next open day 18; s.10 protects.

holdings.text: The Election Commission order admitting the petition was not condonation of delay under proviso to s.85.

anchor.surface_text: We should add that the appellant also raised the contention that if we agreed with him that the election petition was number presented in time, we should hold that the order of the Election Commission admitting the petition was number one of condonation within the proviso to s. 85, because that proceeded on the footing that the petition was in time, and did number amount to a decision that if it was number, there were sufficient grounds for excusing the delay. We are number disposed to agree with this contention but in the view which we have taken that the petition is in time, it is unnecessary to consider it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as petition held in time; court tentatively disagrees with appellant but does not decide.

holdings.text: Rule 118 prohibits employment for payment in connection with election beyond Schedule VI numbers; requires contract of employment superseding normal duties, not mere casual/additional work by regular staff without extra pay.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, neither of these contentions is wellfounded. Rule 118 does number require that the person engaged by a candidate to work in the election should have been specially employed for the purpose of the election. It is sufficient, on the wording of the Rule, that person is employed in connection with the election. At the same time, the requirements of Rule 118 are number satisfied by proving merely that the person does work in connection with the election. That work must be done under a contract of employment. Thus, if the candidate has been maintaining a regular staff of his own and its members have been doing personal service to him and he has been paying them and then the election supervenes, and off -and on he sets them on election work but they continue to do their normal work as members of his staff, it cannot be said of them that they have been employed in connection with the election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'employed for payment in connection'; requires supersession of normal work or extra payment; distinguishes ad hoc vs regular staff casual help; salary for normal duties not election expense.

holdings.text: No finding that 25 staff relieved of normal duties for election work; evidence shows additional out-of-hours work; thus no contravention of Rule 118 or corrupt practice u/s 123(7).

anchor.surface_text: But there is numberfinding that having regard to the work which they are proved to have done, they must be taken to have been relieved of their original work and put on election work. In the absence of such a finding, it cannot be held that Rule II 8 had been infringed. ... The evidence adduced by the first respondent is very largely, to the effect that the appellants men did election work in the morning or in the evening, that is , out of office hours. That shows that the work the staff was in addition to their normal duties, and on the, principles stated above, they could number be held to have been employed in connection with the election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Rule 118 interpretation to facts; Tribunal finding inadequate; evidence insufficient for relief from duties.

holdings.text: Burden on election petitioner to prove Rule 118 infringement.

anchor.surface_text: As the first respondent does number appear himself to have under-, stood the true position under Rule 118 and has failed to adduce, evidence requisite for a decision of the question, he must fail, the burden being on him to establish that Rule had been infringed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner failed to adduce requisite evidence on true legal test.

precedents.citation: Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote 1 ; 1 I894 L.R. 21 I.A. 171

anchor.surface_text: in Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote  1 , and, after Independence, became merged in the State of Pepsu. The  1   I894  L.R. 21 I.A. 171. appellant companytinues to retain a large staff of subordinates, and the charge of the first respondent in his petition was that as many as 54 of them were employed for purposes of election, and that Rule 118 had thus been violated.

precedents.case_name: Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote
precedents.cited_proposition: judicial recognition of Faridkot as an independent State during British regime

anchor.surface_text: In the Hartlepools Case 1  the question arose with reference to one Butler who was the general secratary of Mr. Furness, the returned candidate, and certain clerks in a companypany in which Mr. Furness, had companysiderable influence. All these persons had taken part in the election. As regards Butler, Phillimore J. observed that if it companyld be held that at the time of his employment his duties included also work in elections if and when they, were held, then a proportionate part of his salary should be regarded as election expenses but, on the facts, he held that it was numberpart of the duties of Butler in respect of his standing employment to be election agent when called upon, and that, therefore, numberpart of his salary need be shown as election expenses.

precedents.cited_proposition: whether salary of existing employees doing election work constitutes election expenses or employment for payment in connection with election
precedents.cited_holding: if business man takes his business clerks and employs them for election work, ought to return their salaries as part of his expenses; but point not decided

precedents.citation: Borough of Oxford Case 2 ; 2 7 OM. H. 49, 56-57

anchor.surface_text: In view of the remarks of Sankey, J., in the Borough of Oxford Case  2 , in the  1  1910 6 OM. H. 1.  2  7 OM. H. 49, 56-57 companyrse of his argument, it is doubtful,,how far the observations of Phillimore, J. quoted above companyld be accepted as good law.

precedents.cited_proposition: remarks doubting acceptance of Phillimore J.'s observations in Hartlepools Case

anchor.surface_text: They Were, however,. adopted in two decisions of the Election Tribunals of this companyntry, to which our attention was invited by Mr. Chatterjee.In the Amritsar Case 1 , the following observation occurs We also companysider that if any man in the service of the respondent were put on election work, their wages for the period should have been shown in the return.

precedents.cited_proposition: if employee put on election work, wages for the period should be shown in return

anchor.surface_text: See Hartlepools Case 2  . The words put on election work in this passage suggest that the employees had been taken out of their original work. As there is numberdiscussion of the present question, the authority of this decision is, in any event, little.

precedents.cited_proposition: reference to support Amritsar Case observation on election work

anchor.surface_text: In Farrukhabad Case 3 , this passage,, as also the observations of Phillimore, J., were quoted, and in accordance therewith, it was held that the salaries of Tilakdhari Singh, Kundan Singh and Drigpal Singh for the period they worked in companynection with the election of the respondent Nol should have been shown in the return

precedents.cited_proposition: salaries of employees working in connection with election should be shown in return where they devoted themselves to election work exclusively or for periods

anchor.surface_text: This argument proceeds on an interpretation of s. 10 of the General Clauses Act which, in our opinion,is erroneous.Broadly stated, the object of the section is to enable a person to do what he could have done on a holiday, on the next working day. Where, therefore, a period is prescribed for the performance of an act in a court or office, and that period expires on a holiday, then according to the section the act should be considered to have been done within that period, if it is done on the next day on which the court or office is open. For that section to apply, therefore, all that is requisite is that there should be a period pres- cribed, and that period should expire on a holiday. Now, it cannot be denied that the period of fourteen days provided in Rule I 1 9  a  for presentation of an election petition is a period prescribed, and that is its true character, whether the words used are within fourteen days or number later than fourteen days.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Election Tribunal is set aside and the election petition of the first respondent will stand dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: That the distinction sought to be made by the appellant between these two expressions is without substance will be clear beyond all doubt, when regard is had to s. 81 of the Act. Section 81  1  enacts that the election petition may be presented within such time as may be prescribed, and it is under this section that Rule 119 has been framed. It is obvious that the rule- making authority could number have intended to go further than what the section itself had enacted, and if the language of the Rule is construed in conjunction with and under the coverage of the section under which it is framed, the words number later than fourteen days must be held to mean the same thing as within a period of fourteen days. Reference in this connection should be made to the heading of Rule 119 which is, Time within which an election petition shall be presented . We entertain numberdoubt that the legislature has used both the expressions As meaning the same thing, and there are accordingly numbergrounds for holding that s. 10 is number applicable to petitions falling within Rule 119.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Election Tribunal is set aside and the election petition of the first respondent will stand dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We entertain numberdoubt that the legislature has used both the expressions As meaning the same thing, and there are accordingly numbergrounds for holding that s. 10 is number applicable to petitions falling within Rule 119. We are also unable to read in the proviso to s. 37 of the Act an intention generally to exclude the operation of s. 10 of the General Clauses Act in the construction of the Rules, as that will be against the plain language of Rule 2  6 . It should be numbered that proviso applies only to s. 30  c  of the Act, and it is possible that the Legislature might have considered it doubtful whether s. 30  c  would, having regard to its terms, fall within s. 10 of the General Clauses Act and enacted the province abundant cauterize. The operation of such a beneficent enactment as a. 10 of the General Clauses Act is number, in our opinion, to be cut down on such unsubstantial grounds as have been urged before us. We are accordingly of opinion that the petition which the respondent filed on May 18, 1954, is entitled to the protection afforded by that section and is in time.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Election Tribunal is set aside and the election petition of the first respondent will stand dismissed.

Rule 118 does number require that the person engaged by a candidate to work in the election should have been specially employed for the purpose of the election. It is sufficient, on the wording of the Rule, that person is employed in connection with the election. At the same time, the requirements of Rule 118 are number satisfied by proving merely that the person does work in connection with the election. That work must be done under a contract of employment. Thus, if the candidate has been maintaining a regular staff of his own and its members have been doing personal service to him and he has been paying them and then the election supervenes, and off -and on he sets them on election work but they continue to do their normal work as members of his staff, it cannot be said of them that they have been employed in connection with the election.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Election Tribunal is set aside and the election petition of the first respondent will stand dismissed.
